newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean stock market roiled by takeover frenzy.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean stock market roiled by takeover frenzy.

text.p: Two South Korean companies revealed on Thursday they were considering a grab for a leading department store chain in what would be the first major hostile takeover on the stock market.
The Midopa Department Store chain operates a flagship store in Seoul's most fashionable shopping district and has smaller branches elsewhere in the capital and other cities.
There had been rumours for months that South Korea's largest edible oil company was planning a corporate raid on the chain to get into the distribution business.
The rumours have sent Midopa's share price rocketing from a year low of 7,060 won ($8.14) to a high of 47,500 on Thursday.
Shindongbang Corp had denied the market talk, but on Thursday told the Korea Stock Exchange it was considering a takeover through a public tender offer.
Hours later, Korea Industrial Co stunned the market by announcing it too was thinking of making a similar bid for the retailer.
In a further twist, the president of Korea Industrial is a younger brother of the president of Shindongbang.
Hostile takeovers are virtually unheard of in South Korea, partly because they are considered unethical. Friendly takeovers through private contact with the owners have been the only real option.
However, predatory mergers and acquisitions are expected after the government implements new rules in April.

Takeovers will still not be easy. Under the new regulations, individuals or companies wanting to take over a firm must buy a controlling stake through a tender offer at the highest price reached by the targeted company's shares in the previous 12 months.
A 10 percent ceiling on individual stock holdings in listed companies, which previously made takeovers all but impossible, was lifted in January.
That has given a window of opportunity to would-be raiders before April.
"As merger and acquisition rules will be stricter than expected, corporate raiders will try to complete their deals before April," said a securities watchdog official.
Traders speculated that Korea Industrial, an animal feed maker, was working with Shindongbang on the takeover.
But Shindongbang denied this.
"The two companies are totally different enterprises and they have not negotiated any such deal," chief spokesman Yoo Seung-kwan said in an interview.
"As we announced today, we will soon decide whether to buy a stake in Midopa or not."
Shares in Dainong Corp, Midopa's parent, went limit down to 10,100 won ($11.64).
"We will closely watch the developments as 'consideration' doesn't mean they have decided on a hostile takeover," Park Sang-chul, managing director of Dainong Corp, said by telephone.
Analysts said Midopa would be an easy backdoor entry for Shindongbang into the lucrative distribution trade.
"It would be much cheaper rather than starting a business from scratch, said Kim Min-tae, senior economist at LG Research and Economic Institute.
Greta Park, retail analyst at ING-Barings, said: "If Shindongbang really has the intention to get into the retail business, this may be good news for Midopa."
Midopa closed 3,600 won down on Thursday at 41,500 won.
(Conversion $1 = 867.50)
